claim.text: subsurface horizontal flow through gravel beds planted with Phragmites, Typha, or regionally appropriate emergent species
claim.claim: Phragmites and Typha are appropriate plant species for subsurface flow constructed wetlands

results.summary: Phragmites (common reed) and Typha (cattail) are among the most widely documented and commonly used plant species in subsurface flow constructed wetlands worldwide.
results.detail: Based on established technical literature in wastewater treatment and constructed wetland design, Phragmites australis (common reed) and Typha species (cattails) are the two most frequently cited and used emergent macrophytes for subsurface flow constructed wetlands. They are referenced extensively in EPA guidance documents, academic texts on constructed wetlands (including Kadlec and Wallace's 'Treatment Wetlands'), and international wastewater treatment guidelines. These species are valued for their extensive root systems that support microbial communities, their tolerance of saturated conditions, and their ability to transfer oxygen to the rhizosphere. Note: This verification is based on established technical knowledge rather than live web search, as web tools were unavailable.
sources: Kadlec, R.H. and Wallace, S. (2009) Treatment Wetlands, Second Edition, CRC Press
UN-Habitat technical guides on constructed wetlands

claim.text: BOD reduction should exceed 85%
claim.claim: 85% BOD reduction is the standard threshold for properly functioning greywater wetlands

results.summary: 85% BOD reduction is commonly cited as good performance for constructed wetlands, but it is not a universal 'standard threshold' — actual standards vary by jurisdiction and application.
results.detail: Constructed wetlands treating greywater commonly achieve 80-95% BOD removal when properly designed and maintained, so 85% is a reasonable benchmark figure. However, regulatory standards vary significantly by jurisdiction — some require specific effluent concentrations (e.g., 30 mg/L BOD) rather than percentage reduction, while others may set different thresholds. The claim presents 85% as 'the standard threshold' which overstates the uniformity of regulatory requirements. EPA guidance documents and academic literature on constructed wetlands typically report ranges of performance rather than a single universal standard.
